cv: Zhong, L.-W., Lan, Y.-P., Tang, X.-W., Huang, W.*, He, J.-W., & Liu, S.-W. (2025). From classical models to neural operators: a study on mooring tension prediction for floating offshore wind turbine. Advanced Steel Construction, 21(4), 357–366.

title: Experimental study on tensile and compressive properties of neosinocalamus affinis-based bamboo scrimber
abstract: Engineered bamboo has emerged as a promising material for sustainable construction. However, its mechanical performance varies significantly depending on species and manufacturing processes. Among these, neosinocalamus affinis-based bamboo scrimber (NABS) shows strong potential as a structural material, but its mechanical properties remain insufficiently characterized. This study systematically investigates the mechanical behavior of NABS through tensile and compressive tests along the longitudinal, radial, tangential, and 45◦off-axis fiber orientations. Digital image correlation (DIC), video extensometer, and strain gauges are employed to capture the stress-strain responses. At the same time, macroscopic observations and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) are utilized to examine the fracture mechanisms. The experimental results reveal that NABS displays exceptional mechanical properties, particularly in the fiber-parallel orientation, achieving a tensile strength of 214.33 MPa, elastic modulus of 24.23 GPa, compressive strength of 110.50 MPa, and elastic modulus of 29.38 GPa. These properties demonstrate superior tensile performance, surpassing those of conventional timber and other engineered bamboo products of tensile performance two to three times, while maintaining competitive compressive performance. However, pronounced anisotropy leads to significantly reduced strength and stiffness perpendicular to fiber orientation. The extended Hankinson’s formula is applied to predict off-axis mechanical properties, achieving strength and elastic modulus prediction errors below 10 %. To support structural design, characteristic strength and modulus values are derived using nonparametric and parametric methods, respectively. A direction-specific stress-strain model is also developed to describe the anisotropic behavior of NABS. These findings enhance the fundamental understanding of NABS mechanics and provide guidelines for optimizing structural design parameters, promoting the adoption of engineered bamboo materials in sustainable infrastructure.
APA: Gu, Z.-Z., Li, G., Zhang, M., Looi, D. T.-W., & Liu, S.-W. (2025). Experimental study on tensile and compressive properties of neosinocalamus affinis-based bamboo scrimber. Construction and Building Materials, 492, 143059.
cv: Gu, Z.-Z., Li, G., Zhang, M., Looi, D. T.-W., & Liu, S.-W.* (2025). Experimental study on tensile and compressive properties of neosinocalamus affinis-based bamboo scrimber. Construction and Building Materials, 492, 143059.

title: Design and fabrication of Hong Kong’s first constructional 3D-printed metal pavilion ‘Weaving Love’
abstract: ‘Weaving Love’ is Hong Kong’s first outdoor pavilion constructed using the constructional 3D metal printing through Wire Arc Additive Manufacturing (WAAM) technology, making a transformative milestone in the application of this emerging technology for large-scale construction in the region. This paper documents the entire process—from the concept and design to fabrication and construction—of the “Weaving Love” pavilion, a constructional 3D-printed metal structure situated at the New Immigration Headquarters of Hong Kong. The project demonstrates the seamless integration of advanced WAAM technology, innovative parametric design, and collaborative efforts among government, industry, and academia. By leveraging these advanced technologies, the project team has created a structure that is not only visually stunning but also environmentally friendly and cost-effective—achievements that would have been unattainable using conventional construction methods. The project achieved significant reductions in construction time, cost, and material waste while pushing the boundaries of architectural design and structural engineering. The structure is one of the largest 3D-printed steel structures in the Hong Kong region, designed in accordance with established codes of practice, just like conventional steel structures. This pioneering project successfully utilized WAAM technology to bring the innovative design of an artistic expression to fruition, incorporating advanced structural analysis methods, optimization techniques, and supplementary physical tests. This paper presents summarized project data and methodological frameworks for implementing WAAM technology in construction applications, thereby contributing to the advancement of WAAM technology in construction industry.
APA: SO, D. K.-L., WONG, B. C.-P., SIU, T. S.-K., XI, N., CHAN, S.-L., & LIU, S.-W. (2025). Design and fabrication of Hong Kong’s first constructional 3D-printed metal pavilion ‘Weaving Love’. Scientific Reports, 15, 32982.
cv: SO, D. K.-L., WONG, B. C.-P., SIU, T. S.-K., XI, N., CHAN, S.-L., & LIU, S.-W.* (2025). Design and fabrication of Hong Kong’s first constructional 3D-printed metal pavilion ‘Weaving Love’. Scientific Reports, 15, 32982.

title: Improved finite-element-based stress analysis method for cylindrical orthotropic members with arbitrary cross-sections considering ring orientation
publisher: Institution of Structural Engineers. Published by Elsevier Ltd.
abstract: The main objective of this study is to develop a novel finite element analysis (FEA) method for the stress analysis of cylindrical orthotropic members with arbitrary cross-sections made of timber and then extend it to engineered bamboo. These materials exhibit complex mechanical behavior described by both material anisotropy induced by ring orientation and geometric complexity associated with arbitrary cross-sectional shapes. The proposed approach introduces an orthotropic constant strain triangle (OCST) element, which offers high adaptability in meshing arbitrary shape of cross-sections while considering material anisotropy of cylindrical orthotropic members. The cross-sectional characteristic of timer is distinguished by an advanced cylindrically orthotropic material model. The torsional and shear properties of the orthotropic member are derived based on the assumption of Saint-Venant while considering complex loading conditions. The proposed methods have been programmed into the latest edition of the educational structural analysis software, MSASect2. The results of the present study are compared with established analytical and numerical solutions, followed by two sets of case studies to examine the effects of ring orientation and cross-sectional shape on the distribution of the stress.
APA: Xue, H., Li, Y.-L., Zhao, X.-L., Chen, L., & Liu, S.-W. (2025). Improved finite-element-based stress analysis method for cylindrical orthotropic members with arbitrary cross-sections considering ring orientation. Structures, 80, 110109.
cv: Xue, H., Li, Y.-L., Zhao, X.-L., Chen, L., & Liu, S.-W.* (2025). Improved finite-element-based stress analysis method for cylindrical orthotropic members with arbitrary cross-sections considering ring orientation. Structures, 80, 110109.

title: Fatigue life prediction for corroded butt welds made of 1.4301 stainless steel and Q460 high-strength steel: Numerical analysis and new design rules
publisher: Institution of Structural Engineers. Published by Elsevier Ltd.
abstract: In a corrosive environment, the weld is highly susceptible to both corrosion and fatigue. This exposure can lead to the initiation of fatigue cracks and even result in the complete failure of structures. However, no established design guidelines were available for predicting the fatigue life of corroded butt welds made of 1.4301 stainless steel and Q460 high-strength steel. To address this, this study presents an extensive numerical analysis to develop a new fatigue life prediction model for corroded 1.4301 stainless steel and Q460 high-strength steel with transverse and longitudinal butt welds. Finite element (FE) models incorporating the material non-linearity and initial geometric imperfections obtained from the 3D scanning were developed and the accuracy of FE models was verified against the corresponding experimental findings. A detailed parametric study was subsequently undertaken using the validated FE models, and a total of 128 FE results were generated. Variables which were examined included the mass loss rate and the corrosion rate. The parametric study findings indicated that the fatigue life of corroded welds was significantly influenced by the mass loss rate. Finally, new prediction models for determining the fatigue life of corroded butt welds were proposed, which can establish the relationship between the mass loss rate and the fatigue life. The newly proposed prediction model can closely predict the fatigue life of corroded welds made of two materials.
APA: Feng, R., Yu, Y., Lau, H. H., Chen, B., Deng, X., & Liu, S.-W. (2025). Fatigue life prediction for corroded butt welds made of 1.4301 stainless steel and Q460 high-strength steel: Numerical analysis and new design rules. Structures, 80, 109825.
cv: Feng, R., Yu, Y., Lau, H. H., Chen, B.*, Deng, X., & Liu, S.-W. (2025). Fatigue life prediction for corroded butt welds made of 1.4301 stainless steel and Q460 high-strength steel: Numerical analysis and new design rules. Structures, 80, 109825.

title: Investigating temperature effects on the natural frequency of the hidden frame glass curtain wall’s panel units
abstract: As the facade of buildings, the glass curtain wall is always exposed to the outside environment. Temperature can significantly impact the dynamic characteristics of the panel unit (PU). However, the mechanism by which temperature influences natural frequencies remains unclear. This paper investigates the effects of temperature on the elastic modulus of structural sealant and the natural frequency of PU of the hidden frame glass curtain wall. 24 specimens with the dimension of 12 mm × 12 mm × 50 mm were fabricated and conducted tensile tests at the temperature ranged from −20 ◦C to 50 ◦C to investigate the variations of elastic modulus of structural sealant with temperature. Two full-size PUs were cyclic heated by 6 electric heaters and tested to identify the instantaneous frequencies of the temperature-varying PUs. The results indicate that when the temperature increased from −20 ◦C to 50 ◦C, and the elastic modulus of the structural sealant decreased by 57.3 %. The natural frequencies of the PU decrease with increasing temperature. Two panel units, with an average change of −0.189 % and −0.205 % in the first eight frequencies at each degree Celsius. Then, the finite element method is used to analyze the test specimen and illustrate the mechanism of the temperature’s influence. The numerical analysis results show that the elastic modulus of structural sealant is temperature-dependent and primarily drives the changes in the natural frequencies of the PU under varying temperatures. The influence of temperature on the dynamic characteristics is related to the height-width ratio of the PU. The rate of natural frequency with respect to temperature increases with the increase of the height-width ratio of the PU until the height-width ratio reaches 3. These findings can provide insights to guide the maintenance of the PUs on the hidden frame glass curtain wall in practice, especially where temperature varies significantly under weather or over seasons.
APA: Jiang, K., Pan, D., Huang, Y., Ouyang, W., & Liu, S.-W. (2025). Investigating temperature effects on the natural frequency of the hidden frame glass curtain wall’s panel units. Journal of Building Engineering, 112, 113648.
cv: Jiang, K., Pan, D.*, Huang, Y., Ouyang, W., & Liu, S.-W. (2025). Investigating temperature effects on the natural frequency of the hidden frame glass curtain wall’s panel units. Journal of Building Engineering, 112, 113648.

title: Refined FE-based cross-section analysis for line element simulation of WAAM steel members considering anisotropy
publisher: Institution of Structural Engineers. Published by Elsevier Ltd.
abstract: Wire-arc additive manufacturing (WAAM) has emerged as a promising technique for fabricating large-scale 3D-printed steel structures. However, the development of its full potential is constrained by the current line element-based second-order analysis method for steel structures, which fails to account for the material anisotropy inherent in WAAM. This study addresses this limitation by reformulating the cross-sectional properties utilized in line elements, incorporating an anisotropic material model that accounts for the effect of the printing direction. A 2D finite element analysis (FEA) is employed for numerical solutions of the cross-sectional properties, which are then implemented into a 7-degrees-of-freedom (DOF) Timoshenko line element. The proposed method is validated through comparisons with benchmark results from sophisticated finite element analyses (SFEA). This research provides a novel approach to accurately model WAAM steel members in second-order analysis, which has been incorporated into the MSASect2 software for both research and educational purposes.
APA: Zhang, H.-Y., Liang, A.-R., Liu, S.-W., Liu, Y.-P., & Chan, S.-L. (2025). Refined FE-based cross-section analysis for line element simulation of WAAM steel members considering anisotropy. Structures, 81, 110236.
cv: Zhang, H.-Y., Liang, A.-R., Liu, S.-W.*, Liu, Y.-P., & Chan, S.-L. (2025). Refined FE-based cross-section analysis for line element simulation of WAAM steel members considering anisotropy. Structures, 81, 110236.

title: Initial geometric imperfections of modules in modular integrated construction structures
abstract: Modular Integrated Construction (MiC) structures possess unique sources of initial geometric imperfections that differ significantly from those found in traditional steel structures. Conventional design approaches, which often focus on element-level or non-structural deviations, fail to adequately capture these module-level imperfections, potentially leading to substantial errors in structural assessment and design. This study addresses this critical gap by proposing mathematical models that characterize module-level imperfections based on localized manufacturing tolerances. The effectiveness of the models is validated through Monte Carlo simulations, which establish clear relationships among allowable tolerances, module dimensions, and geometric deviations. By enabling the direct consideration of initial imperfections at the modular unit level, the proposed method fully leverages the high-precision nature of MiC and supports efficient structural design using the Direct Analysis Method (DAM) without reliance on the effective length method. Furthermore, the statistical analysis of manufacturing tolerances provides a foundation for setting appropriate precision requirements to ensure desired module quality. This approach offers a practical and reliable solution for the performance-based design of MiC structures.
APA: Ding, Y.-Y., Liu, Y.-P., Liu, S.-W., Tang, Y.-Q., & Chan, S.-L. (2025). Initial geometric imperfections of modules in modular integrated construction structures. Engineering Structures, 344, 121406.
cv: Ding, Y.-Y., Liu, Y.-P.*, Liu, S.-W., Tang, Y.-Q., & Chan, S.-L. (2025). Initial geometric imperfections of modules in modular integrated construction structures. Engineering Structures, 344, 121406.

title: Physics-informed deep operator networks for rapid nonlinear analysis of glass panes under variable wind-induced loads
abstract: The structural analysis of glass panes under variable and non-uniform wind-induced loads is critical for optimizing building design and enabling proactive structural monitoring. The geometric nonlinearity of glass panes, governed by the Föppl-von Kármán (FvK) equations, poses significant computational challenges due to the complexity of solving high-order partial differential equations (PDEs). While Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) effectively embed physical laws to solve PDEs, their limited generalization across diverse loading conditions often necessitates retraining. Conversely, Deep Operator Networks (DeepONets) map input functions to response fields and perform inference in milliseconds without retraining, but the data-driven DeepONets require large labeled datasets. This study introduces a Physics-Informed Deep Operator Network (PI-DeepONet) framework that combines operator learning with physical constraints to solve the FvK equations, significantly reducing data dependency while maintaining robust generalization to unseen load scenarios. By incorporating hard constraints, the framework ensures precise enforcement of boundary conditions and reduces the order of FvK equations, enhancing training stability and efficiency. Computing derivatives using finite difference and reusing branch network outputs during training further improve computational efficiency. Numerical experiments demonstrate that PI-DeepONet achieves accuracy comparable to traditional finite element methods while performing inference in 2 ms, enhancing the computational efficiency of uncertainty analysis by orders of magnitude. This enables rapid performance evaluation and supports resilient structural design under diverse wind conditions, offering a transformative approach for glass pane analysis and other thin-plate structures.
APA: Ouyang, W., Ouyang, W., Pan, D., Liu, S.-W., & Chan, S.-L. (2026). Physics-informed deep operator networks for rapid nonlinear analysis of glass panes under variable wind-induced loads. Engineering Structures, 346, 121584.
cv: Ouyang, W., Ouyang, W., Pan, D., Liu, S. W.*, & Chan, S. L. (2026). Physics-informed deep operator networks for rapid nonlinear analysis of glass panes under variable wind-induced loads. Engineering Structures, 346, 121584.

title: Seismic performance and failure analysis of prefabricated structural-insulated CFS-foam concrete walls with strawboard sheathing
abstract: A novel prefabricated composite wall system, integrating foam concrete (FC)-infilled cold-formed steel (CFS) with strawboard sheathing (FC-CFS-SS), is proposed to achieve synergistic structural and thermal performance. This system combines the load-bearing capacity of CFS, the insulating properties of FC and strawboard sheathing, and the sustainable use of agricultural straw, ensuring both mechanical integrity and energy efficiency. Thermal analysis indicates that a 216 mm thick wall with 80 mm CFS studs and 700 kg/m3 foam concrete attains 65 % compliance with energy efficiency standards in hot-summer/cold-winter climate zones. Quasi-static cyclic tests revealed a shear-dominated failure mechanism, characterized by a well-defined sequence: damage initiated as localized wrinkling and subsequent tearing of the strawboard sheathing around screw connections, accompanied by extensive diagonal cracking in the FC infill due to shear stresses, eventually involving the CFS frame in a multi-stage, ductile energy-dissipating process. The walls exhibited pinched yet stable hysteresis loops, with progressive stiffness and strength degradation and nonlinear skeleton curves lacking distinct yield plateaus, indicating satisfactory energy dissipation capacity. Parametric studies ranked the influence of key factors on lateral capacity: the presence of FC, wall thickness, sheathing configuration, and FC strength, with increased wall thickness providing synergistic enhancement to both thermal and seismic behavior. Finally, comparative evaluation with existing foam concrete-infilled wall systems confirmed the FC-CFS-SS wall system’s balanced multi-performance, supporting its potential in sustainable prefabricated construction.
APA: Ding, X., Zhang, J., Liu, S.-W., & Chen, Z. (2026). Seismic performance and failure analysis of prefabricated structural-insulated CFS-foam concrete walls with strawboard sheathing. Engineering Failure Analysis, 183, 110194.
cv: Ding, X.*, Zhang, J., Liu, S.-W., & Chen, Z. (2026). Seismic performance and failure analysis of prefabricated structural-insulated CFS-foam concrete walls with strawboard sheathing. Engineering Failure Analysis, 183, 110194.

title: Low-cycle fatigue of laser-arc hybrid welded S960 high-strength steel joints
abstract: High-strength steel (HSS), particularly grade S960, has gained increasing attention in structural engineering due to its superior strength-to-weight ratio, enabling sustainable and lightweight structural design. However, conventional methods like gas metal arc welding (GMAW) often cause cracking, distortion and fatigue issues in high-strength steels. In contrast, high-power laser-arc hybrid welding (LAHW) offers a reliable alternative with reduced heat input and greater precision. However, its low-cycle fatigue behavior in HSS joints remains underexplored. This study investigates the monotonic and low-cycle fatigue behavior of S960 HSS and its welded joints fabricated using LAHW and GMAW. Tensile and low-cycle fatigue tests were conducted to evaluate strength retention, ductility, and energy dissipation. A nonlinear Chaboche kinematic hardening model was calibrated using experimental data to simulate cyclic plasticity behavior in finite element simulations. The results indicate that LAHW joints retain up to 96 % of the strength of base metal and exhibit superior low-cycle energy dissipation compared to GMAW joints. The proposed model can accurately capture the cyclic stress–strain responses of both the base metal and LAHW joints. This research provides experimental and numerical insights into the fatigue performance of laser-arc hybrid welded S960 HSS, enabling its application in fatigue-prone structural components and promoting the broader use of HSS in modern construction.
APA: Zeng, Z., Li, G., Liu, S.-W., Huang, D.-H., Liu, Y.-P., & Chan, S.-L. (2026). Low-cycle fatigue of laser-arc hybrid welded S960 high-strength steel joints. Journal of Constructional Steel Research, 236, 110040.
cv: Zeng, Z., Li, G., Liu, S.-W., Huang, D.-H., Liu, Y.-P.*, & Chan, S.-L. (2026). Low-cycle fatigue of laser-arc hybrid welded S960 high-strength steel joints. Journal of Constructional Steel Research, 236, 110040.
